mn48:3.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambi, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
mn48:3.3: Now at that time the mendicants of Kosambi were arguing, quarreling and fighting, continually wounding each other with barbed words.
mn48:3.4: They couldn’t persuade each other or be persuaded, nor could they convince each other or be convinced.
mn48:3.5: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha,
mn48:3.6: bowed, sat down to one side,
mn48:3.7: and told him what was happening.
mn48:4.1: So the Buddha said to a certain monk:
mn48:4.2: “Please, monk, in my name tell those mendicants that
mn48:4.4: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to those monks
mn48:4.7: “Yes, reverend,” those monks replied. They went to the Buddha,
mn48:4.8: bowed, and sat down to one side.
mn48:4.10: “Is it really true, mendicants, that you have been arguing, quarreling and fighting, continually wounding each other with barbed words? And that you can’t persuade each other or be persuaded, nor can you convince each other or be convinced?”
mn48:4.12: “What do you think, mendicants? When you’re arguing, quarreling and fighting, continually wounding each other with barbed words, are you treating your spiritual companions with kindness by way of body, speech, and mind, both in public and in private?”
mn48:4.16: “So it seems that when you’re arguing you are not treating each other with kindness.
mn48:4.19: So what exactly do you know and see, you foolish men, that you behave in such a way?
mn48:4.20: This will be for your lasting harm and suffering.”
mn48:5.1: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants:
mn48:5.2: “Mendicants, these six warm-hearted qualities make for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without fighting.
mn48:5.4: Firstly, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with bodily kindness, both in public and in private.
mn48:5.5: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without fighting.
mn48:6.1: Furthermore, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with verbal kindness …
mn48:7.1: Furthermore, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with mental kindness …
mn48:8.1: Furthermore, a mendicant shares without reservation any material possessions they have gained by legitimate means …
mn48:9.1: Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the precepts shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. Those precepts are uncorrupted, unflawed, unblemished, untainted, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to samādhi. …
mn48:10.1: Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the view shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. That view is noble and emancipating, and leads one who practices it to the complete end of suffering.
mn48:10.2: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without fighting.
mn48:11.1: These six warm-hearted qualities make for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without fighting.
mn48:11.2: Of these six warm-hearted qualities, the chief is the view that is noble and emancipating, and leads one who practices it to the complete end of suffering. It holds and binds everything together.
mn48:11.4: It’s like a bungalow. The roof-peak is the chief point, which holds and binds everything together.
mn48:11.5: In the same way, of these six warm-hearted qualities, the chief is the view that is noble and emancipating, and leads one who practices it to the complete end of suffering. It holds and binds everything together.
mn48:12.1: And how does the view that is noble and emancipating lead one who practices it to the complete end of suffering?
mn48:12.2: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this:
mn48:12.3: ‘Is there anything that I’m overcome with internally and haven’t given up, because of which I might not accurately know and see?’
mn48:12.4: If a mendicant is overcome with sensual desire, it’s their mind that’s overcome.
mn48:12.5: If a mendicant is overcome with ill-will,
mn48:12.10: pursuing speculation about the next world,
mn48:12.11: or arguing, quarreling and fighting, continually wounding others with barbed words, it’s their mind that’s overcome.
mn48:12.13: ‘There is nothing that I’m overcome with internally and haven’t given up, because of which I might not accurately know and see.
mn48:12.14: My mind is properly disposed for awakening to the truths.’
mn48:12.15: This is the first knowledge they have achieved that is noble and transcendent, and is not shared with ordinary people.
mn48:13.2: ‘When I develop, cultivate, and make much of this view, do I personally gain serenity and quenching?’
mn48:13.4: ‘When I develop, cultivate, and make much of this view, I personally gain serenity and quenching.’
mn48:14.2: ‘Are there any ascetics or brahmins outside of the Buddhist community who have the same kind of view that I have?’
mn48:14.4: ‘There are no ascetics or brahmins outside of the Buddhist community who have the same kind of view that I have.’
mn48:15.2: ‘Do I have the same nature as a person accomplished in view?’
mn48:15.3: And what, mendicants, is the nature of a person accomplished in view?
mn48:15.4: This is the nature of a person accomplished in view.
mn48:15.5: Though they may fall into a kind of offence for which rehabilitation has been laid down, they quickly disclose, clarify, and reveal it to the Teacher or a sensible spiritual companion.
mn48:15.6: And having revealed it they restrain themselves in future.
mn48:15.7: Suppose there was a little baby boy. If he puts his hand or foot on a burning coal, he quickly pulls it back.
mn48:15.8: In the same way, this is the nature of a person accomplished in view.
mn48:15.9: Though they may still fall into a kind of offence for which rehabilitation has been laid down, they quickly reveal it to the Teacher or a sensible spiritual companion.
mn48:15.10: And having revealed it they restrain themselves in future.
mn48:15.12: ‘I have the same nature as a person accomplished in view.’
mn48:16.2: ‘Do I have the same nature as a person accomplished in view?’
mn48:16.3: And what, mendicants, is the nature of a person accomplished in view?
mn48:16.4: This is the nature of a person accomplished in view.
mn48:16.5: Though they might manage a diverse spectrum of duties for their spiritual companions, they still have a keen interest in the training in higher ethics, higher mind, and higher wisdom.
mn48:16.6: Suppose there was a cow with a baby calf. She keeps the calf close as she grazes.
mn48:16.7: In the same way, this is the nature of a person accomplished in view.
mn48:16.8: Though they might manage a diverse spectrum of duties for their spiritual companions, they still have a keen interest in the training in higher ethics, higher mind, and higher wisdom.
mn48:16.10: ‘I have the same nature as a person accomplished in view.’
mn48:17.2: ‘Do I have the same strength as a person accomplished in view?’
mn48:17.3: And what, mendicants, is the strength of a person accomplished in view?
mn48:17.4: The strength of a person accomplished in view is that, when the teaching and training announced by a Realized One is being taught, they pay attention, focus, give full consideration, and listen well.
mn48:17.6: ‘I have the same strength as a person accomplished in view.’
mn48:18.2: ‘Do I have the same strength as a person accomplished in view?’
mn48:18.3: And what, mendicants, is the strength of a person accomplished in view?
mn48:18.4: The strength of a person accomplished in view is that, when the teaching and training announced by the Realized One are being taught, they find joy in the meaning and the teaching, and find gladness connected with the teaching.
mn48:18.6: ‘I have the same strength as a person accomplished in view.’
mn48:18.7: This is the seventh knowledge they have achieved that is noble and transcendent, and is not shared with ordinary people.
mn48:19.1: When a noble disciple has these seven factors, they have properly investigated their own nature with respect to the realization of the fruit of stream entry.
mn48:19.2: A noble disciple with these seven factors has the fruit of stream entry.”
mn48:20.1: This is what the Buddha said.
mn48:20.2: Uplifted, the mendicants approved of what the Buddha said.
